contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox monarch | name = Yetbarak | image = | caption = | reign = 13th century | predecessor = [[Na'akueto La'ab]] | successor = [[Yekuno Amlak]] | queen = | consort = | spouse = | spouse 1 = | spouse 2 = | offspring = | dynasty = [[Zagwe dynasty]] | father = [[Gebre Mesqel Lalibela]] }} '''Yetbarak''' was ''[[Emperor of Ethiopia|{{unicode|nəgusä nägäst}}]]'' of [[Ethiopia]], and a member of the [[Zagwe dynasty]]. According to [[Taddesse Tamrat]], he was the son of [[Gebre Mesqel Lalibela]].<ref>Taddesse Tamrat, ''Church and State in Ethiopia'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1972), p. 56n.</ref> ==History== Tradition states that Yetbarak ascended to the throne after his father King Lalibela had taken the crown away from his first choice of successor, Yetbarak's cousin [[Na'akueto La'ab]]. Taddesse Tamrat argues that this tradition is based on an official version of events, and theorizes that Na'akueto La'ab had fought with Yetbarak for the throne, and despite initial success Yetbarak became king in the end.<ref>Taddesse Tamrat, pp. 62-4.</ref> Taddesse Tamrat also suggests that Yetbarak was the same individual known in the "official hagiographical tradition" as '''Za-Ilmaknun''', the king of the Zagwe dynasty whom [[Yekuno Amlak of Ethiopia|Yekuno Amlak]] killed and succeeded. Tamrat notes that ''Za-Ilmaknun'' is translated as "The Unknown, the hidden one", an "esoteric term" that has "become a useful escape mechanism in denying that the king killed by Yikunno-`Amlak had anything to do with [[Lasta]]."<ref>Taddesse Tamrat, p. 68 n. 1.</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-reg}} {{s-bef | before = [[Na'akueto La'ab]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Emperor of Ethiopia]] }} {{s-aft | after = [[Yekuno Amlak of Ethiopia|Yekuno Amlak]] }} {{s-end}} [[Category:13th-century monarchs in Africa]] [[Category:Emperors of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Zagwe dynasty]] [[Category:13th-century Ethiopian people]] {{Ethiopia-royal-stub}}
